The income from the store pays the rent for the space and her household expenses for herself and her only daughter.  In order to improve the stock of merchandise at the store, which is low, Yolanda needs to purchase sodas, snacks, and liquor in order to increase the stock and generate more sales so that she can improve the quality of life of herself and her daughter.

loans.use: to stock up on sodas, snacks, personal products, and cleaning products.

loans.name: Sina

texts.en:
V. Sina is a 26 year old stay at home mother. Her husband is a security guard at a local hotel and he earns a salary of $80 per month. He also earns a service fee of $10 per day, and earns an additional $10 each Sunday. V. Sina and her husband have two young children, a son and a daughter.

V. Sina\'s home is in very poor condition and she is requesting a loan for $900 to use to repair her home. She wants to provide her family with a safe and strong home, and she believes this loan will help her do that. In the future, when her children are older, V. Sina would like to get a job at the same hotel where her husband works.

loans.use: Repair home

loans.name: Marwah

texts.en:
Marwah has a 19 years old child. She is a member of MBK who has requested her second loan of $100. The loan will be used primarily to purchase merchandise for her store while, due to her illness, a small portion will be set aside for her medication. Her daily revenue is IDR 200,000 with IDR 20,000 of profit.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her general store

loans.name: Maria Isidra

texts.en:
Maria Isidra is a married woman with three children, two girls and a boy. The boy, age 16, and the younger girl, age 8, are in school, while the oldest daughter helps with the business, working with her mother at the place where she sells shoes. Her husband is a laborer. The salary he earns for that is very low, so Maria Isidra decided to start her own business to help with the household expenses and the education of her children. Initially she started out selling tamales, but over time she got into selling shoes, though she still occasionally sells tamales by special order from old clients.

Maria Isidra is soliciting a loan for the amount of $375 to buy merchandise, specifically shoes for the summer season, since this is a good time for that, and also to supply a big order received by her daughter. She will repay the loan over a period of 6 to 12 months, and she thanks you very much for all the support you offer.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

María Isidra es una mujer casada y tiene tres hijos, dos mujeres y un hombre de 16 años de edad, el cual se encuentra estudiando junto con la hija menor de 8 años, la hija mayor le ayuda en el negocio, ya que trabaja con ella vendiendo en su local. Su esposo es obrero por lo que el sueldo que gana es muy bajo y por ello María Isidra decidió comenzar su negocio propio para ayudar en los gastos del hogar y la educación de sus hijos. Inicialmente empezó vendiendo tamales pero con el tiempo incursionó en la venta de zapatos y le ha ido bien, ahora se dedica de lleno a la venta de zapatos y ocasionalmente vende tamales por pedidos a clientes antiguos.

María Isidra está solicitando un préstamo por la cantidad de US $ 375 para la compra de mercadería, es decir, zapatos de temporada de verano, ya que es una buena época y además para poder surtir un pedido grande que logró obtener su hija, por ello también ofrece pagar el préstamo en un período de 6 a 12 meses y te agradece mucho todo el apoyo que le brindas.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Irshad

texts.en: “I have a family of ten including myself and live in a village in Pakistan. My children who have finished school are employed. Two of my sons operate a Rickshaw (local three wheeled vehicle), but one of them needs to purchase a new Richshaw—we have pooled in some of our savings and require an additional loan.”

loans.use: Purchase a Rickshaw

loans.name: Ayu Nirwati

texts.id:
No free time left for Mrs Nirwati. This mother of 3 children is always full of activities. After finishing her job in the kitchen, she feeds the pigs. One female pig consumes a lot of her time, especially when it gives birth. One female pig, that costs about $75, can give birth 3 times a year. Once it gives birth, we can get 5 to 8 piglets. After breeding it for about 1 to 1.5 months, the piglets can be sold for $16 each. Mrs Nirwati has started this business for a few years. She plans to add 2 more female pigs when she gets enough fund.

Translated from Indonesian by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

Tidak ada waktu luang yang tersisa bagi Ibu Nirwati. Ibu dengan tiga orang anak ini selalu selalu beraktifitas. Setelah selesai didapur ia memberi makan ternak babi peliharaannya. Seekor induk babi bisa menghabiskan banyak waktunya, apalagi bila induk ini melahirkan anak. Induk babi yang dibelinya seharga Rp. 700.000,- ini dalam satu tahun bisa melahirkan sebanyak 3 kali. Sekali beranak bisa 5-8 ekor anak dilahirkan. Setelah dipelihara satu sampai satu setengah bulan anak babi ini bisa dijual Rp. 150.000,- perekor. Ibu Ayu Nirwati baru beberapa tahun mulai beternak babi, rencananya akan menambah 2 ekor induk babi lagi kalau sudah mempunyai dana yang cukup.

loans.use: Adding growing pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more merchandise.

loans.name: Mariluz

texts.es:
Av. Saenz Peña 414, Calleria district, Ucayali department. She is 50 years old and is mother to two children. Her husband is a lathe operator, but with his income it is enough for their household expenses, so Mariluz, with the first loan from Manuela Ramos for S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) decided to start a store to buy motorcycle parts and oil changes.

Currently, her store is located downtown, in a zone with much traffic which suits her business well, and she gets more customers with her offer of a free oil change when they buy the oil.

With the recent loan received from Manuela Ramos for S/. 1,300 (US$ 435.00 approx.), which will be paid in 4 months, she will equip her business with some necessary products and buy 500 rodajes , 100 arms, bolts of different sizes, and glues. In addition, they need to expand their locale.

Mariluz is very happy to have obtained said loan, because her business is growing and so is the wellbeing of her family too, and this is why she is thankful and happy that Manuela Ramos has come to her life.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Mariluz pertenece al Banco Comunal María Montesori, vive en la Av. Sáenz Peña 414, del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 50 años de edad y es madre de 2 hijos, su espose es tornero, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos familiares, es así que Mariluz, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) decide poner una tienda de venta de repuesto de motos y cambio de aceites.

En la actualidad tiene su tienda que esta ubicada en el centro de la ciudad, en una zona muy concurrida que le favorece para su negocio, y capta más clientes con su promoción de cambio de aceites gratis por la compra del mismo producto.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,300 (US$ 435..00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, equipará su negocio con algunos productos necesarios y comprará 500 rodajes, 100 brazos, pernos de diversos tamaños y pegamentos, además necesita ampliar su local

Mariluz está muy contenta por haber obtenido dicho préstamo, ya que su negocio crece y el bienestar de su familia también, y por es está muy agradecida y feliz de que Manuela Ramos haya llegado a su vida.

loans.use: Buying spare parts. Expanding business locale. (Compra de repuestos.  Ampliación de local comercial.)

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 30-year-old Fatuma D.. She is married with two children, aged 3 and 6.

In 2000. Fatuma established a kiosk selling small items such as candy, cigarettes, and water. She now requires a loan of $450 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk.

loans.name: Aun

texts.en:
Mrs. S. and her husband, Morm Phun, live approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married for over twenty years and have two daughters, both who work in the garment factory. Mrs. S., 50, repairs fishing nets for her husband and other local fishermen. Her husband, 54, has been a fisherman for over twenty years. They catch fish from the Tonle Sap River and sell the fish in the village.

Mrs. S. is requesting a loan for the third time in the amount of $200 to purchase fertilizer.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Marina's Group

texts.en:
Marina and Zenaida have been members of the Divine Love Community Bank (Banco Comunal Amor Divino) for 12 years and 1 year respectively. In their community bank, they learned responsibility, saving, managing a business and self-esteem. Marina mentioned that with her savings she bought land and built her house.

Marina is 51 years old, divorced and has a son. Marina has a small general store in the province of San Miguel which is located 3 hours from the city of Ayacucho, where she lives. Her products are brought from Ayacucho. Marina also sells fish, chicken and trout by special order.

Zenaida lives with her partner, is 28 years old and has one daughter. Zenaida has a photocopy and printing store where she also sells photocopiers. It is located on a central street in Ayacucho. Zenaida also will open a café in a local institute.

Marina and Zenaida need loans for 600 soles and 1000 soles. This money will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, oil, soap and to start a new business as a café.

Their savings will be used to build their house, capital for their businesses and their children’s studies. Marina and Zenaida’s dreams are that their children will become professionals in the workforce, earn more capital, have their own homes and give all the best to her daughter.

Translated from Spanish by Gabriel Santamaria, Kiva Volunteer.

Marina y Zenaida pertenecen al Banco Comunal Amor Divino hace 12, 1 año respectivamente. En su Banco Comunal aprendieron a ser responsables, a ahorrar, como administrar su negocio y tener autoestima. Marina menciona que con sus ahorros que reunió en su Banco Comunal compró su terreno y construyó su casa.

Marina es divorciada, tiene 51 años y 1 hijo, Marina tiene una tienda de abarrotes en la provincia de San Miguel ubicada a 3 horas de la ciudad de Ayacucho, ciudad donde vive, sus productos son llevados de Ayacucho. Además Marina vende pescado, pollo, trucha por pedido.

Mientras que Zenaida es conviviente, tiene 28 años y 1 hija, Zenaida tiene una tienda de fotocopias, impresiones y también venta de fotocopiadoras, ubicada en una calle céntrica de la ciudad de Ayacucho. Además Zenaida iniciará un cafetín en un instituto local.

Marina y Zenaida necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar, aceite, jabón y para implementar el nuevo negocio de cafetín.

Sus ahorros lo utilizarán en la construcción de su casa, para incrementar el capital de sus negocios y los estudios de sus hijos. Los sueños de Marina y Zenaida son que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener mas capital, casa propia y darle todo lo mejor a su hija.

loans.use: Marina and Zenaida need loans for 600 soles and 1000 soles.  This money will be used to buy rice, sugar, oil, soap and to start a new business as a café.

loans.name: Maria Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa C. has two 10-year-old girls and a 7-year-old boy, who are in primary school. Her husband works at a company near their town. Seven years ago, she started selling shoes by catalog to help her husband with the costs of the family and to offer a better quality of life to their children.

Now she is requesting a loan of $250, which she will repay in 3 months, to purchase merchandise, mainly for the new spring/summer season. With your help, Tere will be able to continue supporting her husband.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Teresa C. tiene 2 niñas de 10 años y un niño de 7 años quienes cursan la primaria, su esposo es obrero en una empresa cercana a la localidad. Desde hace 7 años se inicio en la venta de zapatos por catalogo para ayudar a su esposo en los gastos de la familia y así ofrecerle una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos.

Ahora solicita un préstamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar mercancía, principalmente de la nueva temporada primavera-verano. Con tu contribución Tere seguirá apoyando a su esposo.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Yawo

texts.fr:
Mr. Yawo K. was born in 1971 in Kpévégo. He is married, and he publishes and sells religious books. He is the author of the majority of the books he sells. After publishing, he delivers the books to religious bookstores in Lomé, the interior of the country, as well as Cotonou in Benin, a neighboring country. This is his first loan, and it will allow him to cover the costs of printing, as well as a portion of the delivery.

Translated from French by Megan Berwick, Kiva Fellow at WAGES.

Monsieur K. Yawo est né en 1971 à Kpévégo. Il est marié et a pour activité principale l’édition et la vente de livres religieux. Il est l’auteur de la plupart des livres qu’il vend. Après édition, il fait la livraison dans les librairies évangéliques de Lomé, de l’intérieur du pays et même à Cotonou au Bénin. Le premier crédit qu’il sollicite lui permettra d’assurer les coûts de l’imprimerie et une partie de ses frais de déplacement.

loans.use: Mr. Kekesi writes and sells books on religious subjects and spiritual guidance. He would like to purchase the materials to print new books.

loans.name: Tunu

texts.en:
This is 30 year-old Tunu M.. She is single and has one child, aged five. In 2005, Tunu established her furniture business in which she is assisted by two employees.

Tunu requires a loan in order to purchase materials for the construction of sofa sets, including sponge and fabric. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately US $40. In the future, Tunu plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility, as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase materials including sponge, cushions and fabric to make new sofa sets.

loans.name: Rosa Esther

texts.es:
Rosa is a hard-working woman who is dedicated to her family and job. She has two young children who feed her desires to overcome obstacles. Rosa is a nurse and as of several years ago, she has also sold shoes and other clothing accessories. She sells her products personally to her neighbors and close friends. Her goal is to be able to buy or rent a space where she can sell her shoes with more stability, but at the moment she cannot afford this expense. In the meantime, she needs to purchase new merchandise in order to fill her orders and expand her client list. With your help, this noble nurse will soon have her own shoe store.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

Rosa es una mujer de mucha dedicación al trabajo y a su familia, tiene dos pequeños hijos, ellos son los que alimentan sus deseos de superación. Rosa es enfermera y desde varios años atrás también se dedica a vender zapatos y otros accesorios de vestir. Ella ofrece sus productos de manera personal a sus vecinos y amigos cercanos. Su meta es poder comprar o alquilar un local donde pueda vender sus zapatos con mayor estabilidad, pero ahora no puede solventar ese gasto. Por lo pronto necesita comprar nueva y novedosa mercadería para satisfacer sus pedidos y ampliar la lista de sus clientes. Con tu ayuda, esta noble enfermera tendrá pronto su propia zapatería.

loans.use: Purchase new merchandise in order to obtain a larger number of clients

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence A. is 46 years and married with six children.  She lives in Lagos, in Nigeria, and owns a business which sells and distributes kerosene and medicinal drugs.  Florence has been working in this area since 2004, and has also been the leader of a microfinance lending group.  In order to meet increased customer demand, Florence needs a loan of $850, which will be used to purchase more kerosene fuel and medicines.

loans.use: To purchase kerosene and medicine for resale.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria O. sells drinks and cooked food in her shop. Maria is a LAPO client. She has been in this business for a long time. She is 43 years old and she is married with 5 children. Maria lives in Satellite town, Lagos state, Nigeria. She needs the loan amount of $700 to buy more drinks and foodstuffs for sale. This she says will expand her business and increase her business productivity. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy drinks and food stuffs for sale

loans.name: Celestino

texts.es:
El señor Celestino está casado, tiene 52 años, con 2 hijos, ninguno depende de él económicamente, sus hijos viven en forma independiente.

El cliente tiene una chapería en su casa, su proyecto es la compra de mayor cantidad de materiales y suministros para su trabajo, cuenta con mucha clientela, pero no puede tomar los compromisos por falta de capital. Él es un señor muy emprendedor tiene como finalidad montar su propio taller ya que en su patio es muy pequeño para esa actividad con él quiere comprar un espacio en donde instalar su taller, es un buen profesional por lo que trabajos no le faltan.
texts.en:
Mr. Celestino is 52 years old and married, with two children. Both children are grown, and no longer depend on Celestino economically. Celestino has an auto repair shop in his home, and he'd like to buy wholesale materials and supplies for his work. He has a large clientele, but he is unable to take all of their orders because of a lack of capital. Celestino is a hardworking man whose goal is to buy a separate space to install his workshop, because the current space on his patio is very small. Celestino is a good professional, and because of this he has no lack of work.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy paint, sandpaper, soldering tins, and others.

loans.name: Ron

texts.en: Mrs. Ron S., 49, is a rice farmer who lives in Chhouk Khsach Commune, Kampong Thom Province. She is married to Mr. Hang Chen, a farmer, and has six children, all of whom are single.  Four are employed as garment workers in Phnom Penh and help to support family monthly with a salary of $100 each.  Two are younger and in school. Because she faces physical difficulty with farming labor, Ron requests a loan of $600 to add her savings to purchase two oxen to use for farming.

loans.use: To add her savings to purchase two oxen to use for farming.

loans.name: Mrs. Youren Say Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Youren S. is the village bank president for eight members who all live in Preak Ta Ker village in Kandal province. She is 27 years old and she is single. She owns a small piece of land where she cultivates both rice and vegetables to earn a living.

Mrs. Youren S. has a problem because she does not have enough money to buy vegetable seeds. She is asking for a loan to buy vegetable seeds in hopes that she will increase her income and improve her living conditions.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term (EoT) loans. Four members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: Buy vegetable seeds

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es:
El señor Manuel V. está muy agradecido con todos ustedes por el gran apoyo que recibió en el préstamo anterior. Su negocio ha crecido bastante y ha podido darles trabajo a dos personas más.
Está solicitando su colaboración para invertir ahora en la compra y venta de aparatos. Su idea es seguir desarrollándose y con este nuevo propósito de comercialización, no tiene duda que lo logrará.
Corresponde a cada uno de ustedes que le brindarán su apoyo para este nuevo proyecto.
texts.en:
Señor Manuel V. is very thankful for all of you and the great support that he received in his previous loan. His business has grown considerably and he has been able to give work to two more people. He is requesting your collaboration to invest now in the purchase and sales of air conditioners and heaters. His idea is to continue developing and with this new commercialization plan, he has no doubt that he will achieve it. He will repay each of you who offers your support to him in this new project.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise (air conditioners and heaters)

loans.name: Azizali

texts.en: Azizali N. is a 56-year-old cattleman who is married and has four children. Owing to his father, who was a farmer, Azizali has been associated with this business since he was young. He purchases the cattle in the local market and then raises and sells them. The cattle are kept in the house and it takes a lot of effort to care for them. Every day, Azizali gets up early in the morning to feed the animals. And all day, until late at night, he is busy looking after the cattle. Azizali says that he works with only one aim in mind: to provide his children with a proper education. Now, Azizali would like to expand his business by purchasing two more calves. With your help, he hopes to achieve his goal.

loans.use: Purchase two calves

loans.name: Belcka Marilin

texts.es:
La señora Belcka pertenece al banco comunal “Las Brisas”, vive en el barrio Inti yacu – Nva Esperanza, del distrito de Bellavista, provincia Bellavista, departamento San Martín. Tiene 26 años y es madre de 2 hijos quienes todavía dependen de ella, es casada, su esposo trabaja repartiendo alimento para cerdos. 
Belcka con el primer préstamo adquirido decide invertir en compra de chanchos lo que realiza desde hace 4 años.

En la actualidad compra chanchos pequeños y los cría en un corral en la casa de su suegra, lo que los vende al por mayor y menor en el mercado de su ciudad  y a los vecinos, esto genera ganancias mensuales lo que permite pagar el prestamo con puntualidad.

Con este prestamo de S/.1, 000 el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprara una chancha (madre) de raza, lo que le permitirá aumentar su crianza.

Belcka refiere que el banco le ha permitido progresar e independizar sus ganancias por lo que esta muy agradecida.
texts.en:
Belcka belongs to the community bank "The Breezes", and lives in the Inti Yacu suburb of Nueva Esperanza town, in the district of Bellavista, in the province of Bellavista, in the department of San Martin. She is 26 years old and is the mother of 2 children who are still dependent on her. She is married and her husband works delivering food for pigs. Belcka used the first loan she acquired to invest in the purchase of pigs, her occupation for the last four years. Currently, she buys piglets and raises them in a pen in the house of her mother-in-law, and then sells them both wholesale and retail, in her town market and to her neighbours. This generates a monthly income which permits her to pay back her loan punctually. With this loan of 1000 soles, which will be repaid in six months, she will buy a sow-pig (breeding pig), which will permit her to increase her livestock numbers. Belcka remarks that the bank has allowed her to progress and make independent earnings, for which she is very grateful.

Translated from Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a sow to use for breeding stock

loans.name: Rahima

texts.ru:
Махмуджонова Рахима 1957 года рождения, замужем, имеет детей. Год назад она при помощи сестры начала свою предпринимательскую деятельность. Она торгует овощами на рынке "Рохи Охан" города Душанбе. У нее много клиентов. Каждый день с ближайших районов приезжают клиенты, чтоб закупит у нее товар. В данный момент она продает морковь, картофель, лук... 
Для увеличения ассортимента и товарооборота, Рахима хочет получить займ в сумме 1000 сомони сроком на 6 месяцев.

 
 
Закуп овощей.
texts.en:
Rahima M. was born in 1957, is married, and has children. A year ago she began her own business with her sister's help. She sells vegetables at the Rohi Ohan market in Dushanbe. She has many customers. Everyday customers come from the surrounding districts to buy her goods. Currently she is selling carrots, potatoes, onions, etc. To expand her selection and sales, Rahima is requesting a 1000 somoni loan with a 6-month term for purchasing vegetables.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of vegetables

loans.name: Abdusattor

texts.en:
K. Abdusattor has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2004. He is a responsible and trustworthy client who has not any loan repayment delays.

Abdusattor is married and has 3 children. He is a loving father and has the reputation of being a hard-working man. He has been selling vegetable oil that he gets from direct suppliers in Iran. It is good quality oil so a lot of customers come to buy to his stall.

Abdusattor also sells fruit in summer. He is applying to KIVA for a business development loan of 4000 STJ for 10 months for opening a specialized trade outlet in one of the crowded bazaars that will permit him to increase business turnover. Abdusattor thanks KIVA for its support in small business development.

loans.use: opening a specialized trade outlet

loans.name: Aura Lilliam

texts.es:
Desde hace 15 años en el Mercado El Bisne de la ciudad de Chinandega, la señora Aura Arbizú se dedica a su negocio de venta de frutas tales como mango, banano, piña, manzana, entre otros y aunque no tiene un establecimiento con buenas condiciones ella busca la forma de mejorar y salir adelante en su negocio.

Hoy en día ella ha acudido a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito para la compra de la frutas y por eso espera ser beneficiada de esta manera y así  adquirir los perecederos para ofertarlos en su localidad y de esta forma continuar con el mejoramiento de su nivel de vida y el de su amada familia.
texts.en:
For 15 years in the El Bisne Market in the city of Chinandega, Mrs. Aura Arbizu has been in the business of selling fruits such as mangoes, bananas, pineapples, apples, among other things. Even though she doesn't have an establishment with good conditions, she is looking for a way to improve and move forward.

Today she has gone to CEPRODEL to acquire a loan to buy fruit. She hopes to benefit in this manner and as such acquire the perishables in order to offer them in her location


Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fruit

loans.name: Alpha

texts.fr:
Monsieur Alpha B. est un fonctionnaire qui fait l’embouche au quartier Cite Lamy de Thiès, une ville située 70 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale de Sénégal.  Il va utiliser le crédit qu’il sollicite pour renforcer son activité qui consiste d’élever des moutons pour les revendre.  Il est âgé de 52 ans et il est marie avec des enfants.

Monsieur B. sollicite un produit spécial de l’IMCEC.  Le produit s’appelle Kiva Program de Développement de l’Enfant et de la Famille (PDEF), et il sert à aider les parents des enfants pauvres qui sont dans le projet de Christian Children’s Fund, l’organisation qui a crée IMCEC.  Les clients profitent d’un taux d’intérêt diminué.
texts.en:
Mr. Alpha B. is a civil servant who fattens livestock in the Cite Lamy district of Thiès, a city locate 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. He's going to use the loan to bolster his business, which involves raising sheep for resale. He is 52 and married and has children.

Mr. B. is requesting a special IMCEC product. The product is called "Kiva Program de Développement de l’Enfant et de la Famille" (PDEF). It's used to help the parents of poor children who are with the Christian Children’s Fund, which is the organization that created IMCEC. Clients benefit from a reduced interest rate.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster his business involving the raising of sheep

loans.name: John

texts.en: John A. has been working as a painter and car sprayer at Siwdo, near Cape Coast, since 2005. He is married with seven dependents. He received an education through junior high school. While John works as a painter, his wife is employed as a seamstress. He is responsible for paying bills and providing food for his family. His loan will be used to buy more paints for his shop and spraying materials for his work. He hopes to reinvest the profits in his business.

loans.use: To buy paints and spraying materials

loans.name: Sugran Muhammad Arshad Group

texts.en:
My name is Sugran and I have been a citizen of Borewala, Pakistan, for the past ten years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines.

I run a business selling clothes. I know that my husband’s income is insufficient to meet the financial expenses which allows me to run a business to produce more income. I save my income and used it as per need. My husband’s name is M. A. and he runs a fertilizer-selling business. I’m applying for a loan to buy fertilizer to expand my husband’s business.

I’m the group leader of four other women from my locality:

Shaheen kosar baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides to sell.

Kosar baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

Razia parveen baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer to sell.

Sakina baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her husband's business

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en: Francisco A. is from the village of Carmen, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 40 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Francisco owns and operates a business venture in the manufacturing sector, primarily engaging in sand and gravel. He uses his skills in manufacturing and selling hollow blocks. He has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Francisco joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Francisco has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to finance his sand and gravel business. Francisco is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase items for a planned sari-sari (variety) store on his business site. This loan will be his 3rd from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of his family and support the education of his children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase items for the planned sari-sari store on his business site

location.town: Carmen, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Ndeye  Aby

texts.fr: Ndeye  Aby N.  est un handicapé physique   elle est évolue dans le secteur  de la couture .Elle a démarrer avec ses propre moyens en achetant une machine a coudre pour confectionner des habits.les habit cousus sont vendus au niveau des groupement de promotion féminine. Avec le prêt qu’elle sollicite elle veut renforcer son activité  en achetant des tissus  et accessoire pour la couture.
texts.en:
Ndeye Aby N. is physically handicapped and has always worked in dressmaking. She began by using her own money to buy a sewing machine to make clothes. She sells the clothes through a “group for women’s advancement" (one of a number of local groups in Senegal that work to promote women’s programs). She wants to use the loan she is requesting to build her business by buying fabric and dressmaking supplies.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Beatrice Akinyi

texts.en: Beatrice A. runs a hotel in Harambee Market in Western Province. She is 35 years old, married to Michael Ouko, and together they have been blessed with three children. Beatrice's "hotel" is actually a restaurant – "hotel" in Kenyan English most commonly refers to a restaurant, but it can also used to refer to an establishment that offers short-term lodging. After successfully completing her first loan, this is the second loan that Beatrice will be getting from KADET. She hopes to use this money to purchase more cooking equipment and ingredients to enable her to serve her clients with more appetizing meals. She also has a desire to start a retail shop beside her hotel. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy cooking equipment, food and other ingredients for use at her restaurant

loans.name: Mary An Janit

texts.en:
Mary An Janit L. is from the village of Dolores, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old. Mary An Janit is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Mary An Janit plants and harvests a variety of vegetables for sale. Mary An Janit has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In February 2009, Mary An Janit joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and to increase her ability to engage in business activities. Mary An Janit has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

Mary An Janit is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Mary An Janit from PMPC. She plans to use some of the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en:
Benedicta N. sells kenkey at Moree Junction near Cape Coast. Benedicta has received a junior high education. She is married and has one child. Her husband is a teacher.

Benedicta has been selling kenkey since 2007. She is responsible for paying her utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more maize for cooking her kenkey, as well as firewood, rappers, and gari to sell at the market. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to give quality education to her children.

loans.use: To buy more maize for cooking kenkey, and firewood, rappers, and gari to sell at the market

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia is a member of the Ngome borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa. She is 39 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 17, 19, 12 years old.

Rukia has owned a food business selling onions, tomatoes and charcoal for 3 years. She works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 120,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Rukia`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 400,000 Tsh in  order to buy more onions, tomatoes and charcoal.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Rukia hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more onions, tomatoes  and  charcoal for  sale

loans.name: Luz Zenaida

texts.es:
El banco comunal Unión Progresista se encuentra ubicado a unos 45 minutos fuera de la ciudad de Cuenca, vía al Valle en la comunidad de Ñariviña, aquí podemos disfrutar de unos hermosos paisajes siendo una comunidad que nos brinda la libertad de estar en el campo, respirar aire puro y admirar la belleza natural de nuestra ciudad. 

La señora Luz L. vive en la comunidad de Pichicay en  la parroquia  Santa Ana, es una joven de  24 años,  es madre soltera de un hijo de 1 año 11 meses de edad, su niño no es reconocido por su padre, ella trabaja como empleada doméstica hace ya varios años para mantener  a su hijo, no tiene casa propia por lo que  vive con su madre.

Luz tiene una buena amistad con todas las socias de su banco comunal, lleva trabajando junto a la fundación tres años, con los créditos obtenidos ha cancelado algunas deudas, mientras que con el préstamo que ESPOIR le entregue va a invertir en la compra de  muebles para su hogar.

El  sueño de Luz es  llegar a tener su  propio  criadero de pollos actividad de corto ciclo y que además deja buenas ganancias para compartir mas tiempo con su niño.
texts.en:
The Unión Progresista Communal Bank is located 45 minutes outside of the city of Cuenca on the way to El Valle in the Ñariviña community. Here we can enjoy beautiful scenery because it is a community that offers the freedom of being in the country, breathing fresh air, and admiration for the natural beauty of this city. Luz L. lives in the Pichicay community in the Santa Ana parish. She is a 24 year old single mother with a child who is one year and eleven months old. Her child is not acknowledged by his father. She works as a domestic employee. She has done this for several years to support her son. She does not have her own house; she lives with her mother. Luz has a nice friendship with all of the other members of her communal bank. She has been working with the foundation for three years. With the loans she has received, she has paid some debts. With the loan from ESPOIR she will buy furniture for her home. Luz’s dream is to have her own chicken coop. This is an activity with a short cycle, and it also produces good income. Then she could spend more time with her son.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy furniture for her home

loans.name: Ek

texts.en: Ek P. is 30 years old and resides in the Takeo province with her husband and two young children. Together with her husband, she makes and sells brooms at the local market to earn a living and they are able to make around $3.00 of profit every day. Ek P. is asking for a loan of $800, which she needs to purchase more materials so that she can make more brooms to sell.

loans.use: To buy materials to make brooms.

loans.name: Raed

texts.en: Raed is a 24-year-old single man who lives with his parents. He has owned a barber shop since 2002 called “Al Read" where he services the neighboring villages. Today, Raed is asking for a loan of $1,000. With the loan, he will buy new tools and new chairs to attract more clients to his shop.

loans.use: To buy tools and chairs for his barber shop

loans.name: Yelena

texts.en:
Yelena is divorced. She has a grown son, Alexander. Yelena is an entrepreneur from Melitopol, where she sells women’s outer clothing in the central city market. She launched this small business 16 years ago. Presently, Yelena has about 21,000 grivnyas in inventory. Her monthly profit amounts to 5,000 grinyas a month.

Yelena is seeking a 10,000 grivnya loan to restock her merchandise and generate additional income. She realizes that access to loans is important for her business. She believes a good array of clothing items will help her better serve the needs of her clients and increase her sales. Additional income will allow her to invest more in her family’s well-being and provide a better living for her son and herself, which is her first priority in life.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Bolanle

texts.en:
Bolanle is 55 years old and married with three children. Her eldest child is 30 years old. Her husband is a printer. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. 

She is a friendly woman and she uses her people skills to attract more customers to her stall. She sells crates of drinks at wholesale prices to her customers. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is requesting a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. 

She says thank you to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Nimfa

texts.en:
Nimfa L. is from the village of Bon Bon in Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 35 years old. Nimfa is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Nimfa sells of coconut and coconut products in the local community. Nimfa has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Nimfa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nimfa is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP to purchase new items to sell. This is Nimfa's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Rosela

texts.en:
Rosela B. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao Mis. Occ. She is 35 years old. Rosela is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosela owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as milo (sachet), shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Rosela has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosela joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosela is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosela from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Gladis Del Socorro

texts.es: Gladis del Socorro M. M. de 41 años desde hace cinco años sale de su casa a tempranas horas ofertando en las casas, empresas e instituciones que se encuentra en su ruta de trabajo cosméticos y prendas de oro y plata. Esta inicio con este negocio para ayudar en su hogar y para que sus hijos tengan una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Gladis del Socorro M. M. is a 41-year-old woman who has been leaving her home very early in the morning to sell cosmetics and gold/silver jewelry at homes, companies, and institutes for five years. She started this business to help out in her household, and so that her children could have a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics and gold/silver jewelry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase fresh fish and spices in bulk

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
Gregoria, de 38 años, vive en su casa propia al lado de sus 2 hijos; José (10) y Carlos (14). Aunque está separada de su esposo, trabaja muy duro cada día para sacar adelante a sus dos pequeños.

Su esposo le dejó una pequeña combi (camioneta para 12 personas) para la brinde en alquiler y así pueda mantener a sus hijos, y así lo hizo. Todos los días a un chofer trabaja con esa camioneta haciendo transporte de pasajeros, siendo el hijo mayor de Gregoria quien hace las veces de cobrador en sus tiempos libres, a pesar de su corta edad también obtiene ganancias por su trabajo. Gregoria también es profesora en un centro educativo primario y se dedica a su profesión todos los días útiles de la semana, medio tiempo, para no descuidar a su hijo más pequeño y con las ganancias de la combi les alcanza para vivir cómodamente. Ella está muy orgullosa de sus hijos porque la ayudan bastante y porque son muy estudiosos y tienen beca en los centros donde estudian, lo que le permite ahorrar bastante dinero. Para el futuro quiere comprar otra combi para brindarla en alquiler y así obtener mayores ganancias.

Este es el primer préstamo que tiene con MFP y está muy agradecida con todas las personas que hacen posible que pueda recibir el crédito para seguir trabajando. Gregoria tiene planeado invertir el dinero que solicita en el cambio de las llantas de su camioneta, ya que están deterioradas y con unas nuevas ofrecerá un mejor servicio.
texts.en:
Gregoria is 38 years old and lives in her own home with her 2 children: José (10) and Carlos (14). Even though she is separated from her husband, she works very hard every day to provide for her two little ones. Her husband left her a small VW van (van for 12 people) so she can rent it and in this way support her children. Every day a chauffeur works with this van to transport passengers. Her eldest son helps out as a payment collector in his free time; despite his young age he obtains some profit from his work. Gregoria is also a teacher in an elementary school and is devoted to her profession part-time every weekday, so that she has enough time for her youngest son. With the earnings from the van they have enough to get by comfortably. She is very proud of her children because they help her out a lot and because they are good students and have a scholarship in their schools, which allows her to save a lot of money. In the future she wants to buy another van to rent it and in this way earn more money. This is the 1st loan she has with MFP and she is very grateful with everyone that makes the loan that keeps her working possible. Gregoria is planning to invest the money in new tires for her van, because the old ones are deteriorated. With the new ones she will be able to offer better service.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Change of tires for her van

loans.name: Help Wesef Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the 'Help Wesef Group' from the small town of Waterloo, near Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city. Members of this group are all local entrepreneurs in Waterloo, where 'Shine on Sierra Leone' has partnered with SMT to start a branch. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,900,000 from Kiva lenders in order to invest in their businesses, make more profit, and consequently improve their living conditions.

Fatmata J. who is pictured on the left is the leader of this group. Fatmata is approximately 47 years old, married to a teacher, and they have 6 children. Two of her children are attending secondary school, two are in primary school and two are already adults. Since childhood, Fatmata has been selling market food – ogiri (used to give sauce a sweet flavor), onions, tola (also used in sauces) and Maggi cubes (used to give sauce a sweet taste). With her share of the loan (SLL 800,000), Fatmata will buy a bag of 'benny' (sesame seeds, used to produce ogiri), 1 carton of Maggi cubes, and 1 bag of onions.

loans.use: Buy a bag of 'benny' (used to produce ogiri), 1 carton of Maggi cubes, and 1 bag of onions

loans.name: Kanyansheko Bakyara Twimukye Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
T. Margaret appears in the small photo at the top right and she also appears in the big group photo as the group leader. She is a married woman with three kids, all going to school.

Margaret is one extraordinary woman, who has chosen a predominantly male occupation - farming. For the last twenty years she has gone through this farming mill in Kanyansheko village, Ibanda district. It’s with her experience and sense of hard work that she has been able to make successful strides in a male-dominated field.

Currently, Margaret is making profits to the tune of 40,000 shillings a month. It’s apparent that these profits are minimal by her standards, and also going by the status quo. Her future plans, on getting a loan, are to expand her business and to improve her family’s welfare.

loans.use: To improve her farm with mulching and more manure

loans.name: Julio Hernán

texts.es: Julio Hernán F. R. de 37 años de edad, reside en el departamento de La Libertad. Vive junto a su madre quien se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar y le ayuda con el negocio. Julio posee una tienda en la cual comercializa productos de primera necesidad, en la cual muchas personas de su cantón como de otros aledaños llegan a su negocio a consumir sus productos, esto debido a que en el lugar que Julio vive no existen muchas tiendas por lo que él desea aprovechar esta situación y poder brindarles más productos de gran utilidad para e hogar. Es por esto que Julio solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de productos alimenticios, como golosinas, bebidas y otros más los cuales son los que mayor  demanda poseen. Julio solicita el préstamo a Integra y posee la ilusión de mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su madre gracias a este.
texts.en:
Julio Hernán F. R., 37 years of age, resides in the community of “The Liberty”. He lives together with his mother, who dedicates herself to the chores at home and she helps him with the business. Julio has a store that markets products of basic necessity which many people of his street, like the others surrounding, come to his business to purchase. This is because in the place that Julio lives, not many stores exist so he wants to make the most of the situation and be able to offer more useful products for the home. This is why Julio requests the loan, through which he can buy larger amounts of food products like candy, drinks, and more that are in high demand. Julio requests the loan to have the hope to better his quality of life and the life of his mother.

Translated from Spanish by Tess Siemer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy comsumable and home related products

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr: Monsieur Mamadou G. est un chauffeur qui gére un mini car pour le transport un commun vers la liaison Mbour Kaolack une autre région du Sénégal . Le but de son crédit est la réparation de son vehicule pour l'achat d'un moteur d'occasion lui permettant de reprendre l'activité qui est le sien . Ainsi monsieur G. père de 6 enfants depend de ce vehicule pour nourrire sa famille et s'occuper à bien de leur éducation
texts.en:
Mr. Mamadou G. is a driver who runs a mini van for public transport towards the Mbour Kaolack line in another region of Senegal. The aim of his credit is for the repair of his vehicle for the purchase of a new second-hand engine which will allow him to take on again his business. Thus, Mr. G., the father of 6 children depend on this vehicle to feed his family and to take good care of their education.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle repair

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Mr. Soeun Saing and his wife, Mrs. San Yoim, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1979 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Two of their children do construction work with their father, and the other two children assist their mother in her farming business. Soeun is not in the photo; his wife was available instead.

Soeun has been a wooden-house builder for more than three years. His wife has been a farmer for more than twenty years. Besides farming, she is a silk weaver as well. 

Soeun does not have enough materials to work, so he is asking for a loan of $600 to purchase construction materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials.

loans.name: Afutiti

texts.en:
Afutiti Saulaulu is 28 years old and married. She has 4 children, ages 1 - 10.  She is starting a business planting, harvesting, and selling taro. Afutiti needs a loan of WST$1000 to purchase weed-killers, such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Afutiti joined SPBD. This is her 1st loan from SPBD. SPBD's loans are Afutiti's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375"

loans.use: To purchase weed-killers, such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Murotjon

texts.en:
R. Murotjon is a married father of 3 children. An electrician by training, he left this trade in favor of farming. It is a very profitable business, which requires significant financial means. Today he needs to expand his cultivatable land and increase his revenues. Murotjon seeks a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer. This will allow him to increase his production and better satisfy his clientele.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Esperanza De Dios1,2,3 Group

texts.en:
Soneta is the coordinator of her group Esperanza de Dios (God's Wish), and her story is representative of both her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in La Romana, an area where the economy is dominated by sugar cane, and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home there in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their three children.

Soneta is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza and to invest in her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her small food stand by purchasing soups, coffee, and rice as well as laundry detergent. She will use the profits to save toward her dream of owning a small corner store. Soneta thanks all of you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase soups, coffee, rice and laundry detergent

loans.name: Rowena Basong Group

texts.en:
Rowena B. is from the village of Sepac Sapang Dalaga Misamis Occidental. She is 55 years old. Rowena is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Shasta Daisy 1.

Rowena is married and has three school-aged children. Rowena owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as candies, soft drinks, sardines, shampoo, soap, & toothpaste in the local community. Rowena has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Rowena joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Rowena's portion of the group loan is 4,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rowena from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Mademoiselle Ama A. is 36 years old and since 2007 has been selling motor oil in Lomé, Togo. Ama has one child to care for and the income she receives from selling motor oil allows her to care for her child. Normally she purchases her oil across the border in Ghana. She is now requesting her second loan from Kiva partner, WAGES, of 200,000 XOF in order to purchase more oil.

loans.use: To purchase motor oil

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en: Mylene F. is from the town of Villa Rose, Cabarroguis, Quirino. She is 31 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Mylene owns and operates a business selling charcoal. She has been engaged in her business for over fourteen years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Mylene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale. Mylene is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her 2nd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has one child, not currently in school. Jane has a business selling charcoal and firewood, which she has had for less than a year. To help expand her business, Jane has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more charcoal and firewood to sell. With the help of the loan, Jane hopes to generate greater profits and be able to buy food and medication for her child. In the future, Jane hopes to own a plot of land. She is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped improve her prospects for the future by teaching her how to expand a business and be self-reliant. Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva that funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterwards, ELA participants can receive micro-finance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional micro-finance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in micro-finance.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood to sell

loans.name: Nodir

texts.ru: Ризоев Нодир проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 43 года. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Образование высшее, преподаватель. Работает по профессии. В свободное от работы время вместе с женой занимается торговлей на рынке "Зенсклад" и "Панчшанбебозор". Он в основном продает разную мелочь и одежду. Сейчас клиент построил магазин у себя дома и хочет его открыть. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота. На полученную прибыль хочет оплатить учебу своего сына.
texts.en:
Nodir R. lives in Yavan. He is 43 years old, married, and has two children. He has a degree in teaching. He works in his trade. During free time from work, he and his wife trade in the Zensklad and Panchshanbebozor markets. He basically sells knickknacks and clothes. Now, the client has built a shop in his home and wishes to open it. He is taking out a loan to increase his sales. With his profits, he would like to pay for his son’s education.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Ingris Patricia

texts.es:
El negocio de Ingris Patricia es la fabricación de artefactos de hierro y de aluminio, pero también tiene un vehículo que utiliza como moto taxi, usualmente usado en el municipio de Malambo como medio de transporte. Inicialmente, cuando su esposo dejó de trabajar como empleado, emprendieron  el  negocio donde ofrecía servicios de alquiler de lavadoras y de video juegos, pero la alta competencia que se generó en esta población relacionada con estas actividades, los obligó a retomar la experiencia de 10 años de su esposo en la fabricación de productos de hierro y  aluminio con los que en la actualidad han logrado  sostenerse en el mercado.
Este es su segundo financiamiento con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con su primero logró aumentar sus ingresos y con ello terminar de construir su apartamento, el que ahora le ofrece nuevos ingresos por concepto de arrendamiento.  Su plan es organizar gradualmente su taller con mejores y más adecuadas herramientas y el mejoramiento locativo del mismo. Con su credikiva comprará  materia prima  como aluminio, hierro, cerraduras, tornillos, tuercas láminas de vidrio remaches y empaques, aprovechará la temporada de fin de año, donde los clientes por obtener ingresos adicionales,  mejoran sus condiciones habitacionales y con ello mandan a fabricar   puertas, rejas y ventanas  en el taller de Ingris. Así ella aspira a aumentar su capital de trabajo, generar mayor número de clientes y mejores sus utilidades que favorecrian su ingreso familiar y el sostenimiento cada vez de mejor calidad,  de sus 3 hijos que están en las edades de 6 a 13 años.
texts.en:
Ingris Patricia's business is the production of iron and aluminum fixtures, but she also has a vehicle which she uses as a moto-taxi [motorcycle outfitted with a passenger compartment], typically used in the municipality of Malambo as a means of transport. At first when her husband stopped working as an employee they set up a business in which they offered washing machine and video game rental services, but the competition that was generated in this community related to these types of businesses was stiff. They were obliged to fall back on her husband's ten years of experience producing iron and aluminum products, by which they currently have successfully maintained their presence in the market. 

This is her second loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. With the first loan she successfully increased her income and thus was able to complete the construction of her apartment, which now offers her new income by way of rental. Her plan is to gradually organize her workshop with better and more appropriate tools and to improve its location. 

She will use her Kiva loan to buy basic supplies such as aluminum, iron, locks, screws, nuts, glass panes, rivets and washers. She will take advantage of the end-of-the-year season during which customers, due to bringing in additional income, typically improve their living conditions and so place orders for doors, grille work and windows from Ingris's workshop. Therefore she hopes to increase her working capital, expand her customer base and raise her profits which would be favorable to the family income and ever-improving quality of life of her three children who range between the ages of 6 and 13.

loans.use: To purchase basic supplies such as aluminum, iron, locks, screws, nuts, panes of glass, rivets and washers

loans.name: Ingrid

texts.es:
Ingrid forma parte del banco comunal “El Eclipse Valdiviano”, perteneciente a la ciudad de Valdivia. Ella hace artesanías en collares, aros y accesorios en tejidos, macrame, crochet, semillas y mostacillas y las vende en un local, el cual  arrienda en una galería de la ciudad hace 6 años. 
Con este préstamo comprará materiales para hacer sus productos artesanales, para lo cual viajará a Santiago, capital de Chile. Su sueño es tener su casa propia, ya que vive con sus papás y su único hijo de 18 años. También le gustaría tener otro local de artesanías, además del que ya tiene, pero en otro lugar. Para el sueño de su casa, Ingrid está ahorrando y esperando un subsidio del Estado, que estima pueda ser aprobado el próximo año. Su gran motivación es contar con los recursos que le permitan dar bienestar económico a su hijo y la oportunidad de tener estudios superiores.  
Para Ingrid Fondo Esperanza ha sido un importante apoyo que le ha permitido mantener su negocio. 
Valdivia es una ciudad del sur de Chile, ubicada en la región de Los Ríos. Se destaca por tener uno de los pocos ríos navegables del país. Valdivia presenta, dentro de sus principales actividades económicas, la industria de la metalurgia, la construcción naval, maderera, papelera, celulosa, cervecera y molinera.
texts.en:
Ingrid is part of the "El Eclipse Valdiviano" communal bank, based in the city of Valdivia.  She crafts items like necklaces, rings, and accessories, which are knit, macramed, crocheted, or made from seeds or beads.  She has sold these items for six years in a store that is located in a shopping gallery in the city.
 
She will use this loan to buy materials for making her artisan crafts, which she travels to Santiago, the capital of Chile, to purchase.  Her dream is to have her own house, as she now lives with her parents and her only son, who is 18 years old.  She would also like to have another shop for her crafts, in addition to her current one, but located elsewhere.  In regards to her dream of owning a house, Ingrid has been saving and is also hoping for a housing subsidy from the state, which she estimates could be approved in the coming year.  Her greatest motivation is to secure the resources that will allow her to provide for her son's economic well-being and for him to have the opportunity for higher education.

Fondo Esperanza has been an important help to Ingrid, as it has made it possible for her to sustain her business.

Valdivia is a city in the south of Chile, located in the Los Ríos ["The Rivers"] region.  It is known for having one of the few navigable rivers in the country.  Valdivia's principal economic activities are metallurgy; naval construction; wood, paper, and pulp production; brewing; and milling.

loans.use: materials for making artisan crafts like necklaces, rings, and accessories

loans.name: Santa María Group

texts.es: Perseverancia, iniciativa y deseo D. desarrollo por salir adelante son parte D. las características primordiales D. la alcancía comunal Santa Ana, conformado por 10 integrantes en su mayoría mujeres desD. hace mas D. 1 año, este grupo viene trabajando D. forma paraje y en constante desarrollo, cada integrante en forma individual, muestra D. ello es la señora Jacinta B. D. 47 años D. edad y madre soltera D. 2 dos hijos D. los cuales uno aun es menor D. edad. Ella se levanta todas las mañanas muy temprano para abrir la bodega que tiene como fuente D. ingresos para su hogar, el cual le ha dado muchas satisfacciones a lo largo D. 8 años que es el tiempo que tiene su bodega. La señora Jacinta B. emprenD. este negocio a raíz del abandono D. su esposo dejándola con dos menores hijos a su cuidado por tanto, necesitaba D. un sustento para poder sacar adelante a su familia. Con el reciente préstamo implementara mercadería  para la campaña naviD.ña. Como la señora Jacinta cada integrante tiene una historia en particular con buenos y malos momentos a lo largo D. sus vidas pero, si en algo coinciden es el deseo D. superación que demuestran todos los días por el bienestar D. sus familias y negocios.
texts.en:
Perseverance, initiative and a desire for development and success have been some of the main characteristics of the Santa Ana communal bank which has 10 members, most of whom are women.  For more than a year this group has been working in such a way, in constant development, every member in their own way.

One of the group's members who demonstrates these characteristics is Jacinta B. who is 47 years old and the single mother of two children, one of whom is still school age.  She gets up very early each morning to open her small grocery store which is the source of income for her household.  It has provided her with a lot of satisfaction over the 8 years for which she has owned it.  Jacinta B. started this business when her husband left her with two young children in her care.  She needed a way to earn a living in order to support her family.  With her recent loan, she will buy merchandise for the Christmas season.  Like Jacinta, every member of the group has their own story with good and bad moments throughout their lives but they all have a desire to overcome obstacles and they demonstrate this every day for the well-being of their families and their businesses.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for the Christmas season

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Life is more than what we could ever imagine. For Liza V., 43, everything could happen. Liza finished only high school, but she makes sure her educational attainment would not get in the way of her living life to the fullest. She currently lives together with Marcelo, and she is the mother of six children.  They live in Pasay City, Philippines.

At present, Liza focuses her entrepreneurial skills on her butcher shop. She knows this is something she can do, given the ten years of experience she has in business and the training she receives from CCT*. She sells pork, chicken meat, and other frozen foods in line with the needs of her customers. Every month, Liza earns Php300 which she uses to meet the needs of her family.

To help grow her business, Liza plans to apply for a Php15,000 loan. She plans to use the money she will receive from the loan to buy more meat products to add to her meat shop, because just as everything could happen to her favor, also, any threat could rise up against her business--and that is something she is getting ready for. Nonetheless, Liza, just like any entrepreneur, dreams of expanding her business and meeting the needs of the  larger community.

Sure enough, Liza faces different kinds of challenges both in the aspect of business and family life. But if in life everything can happen, then surely greater things can happen in her life; more than what she could imagine. All it takes is a heart that masters its fears, and a mind that goes beyond anxieties.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase  meat for her butcher shop

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is from the village of Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City. She is 38 years old. Mary Jane is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Jane owns & operates a specialized retail store in the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mary Jane joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Mary Jane from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase inventory & fund working capital

location.town: Oroquieta-Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occ

loans.name: Angel Armando

texts.es:
Angel Armando Q. T. tiene 28 años de edad, Vive en Unión Libre, vive con la compañera y con los hijos,  vive en el cantón de Ventanas Provincia los Ríos. Tiene 2 hijos.

Los miembros de la V.R.C. SEÑOR DE LA SALUD  se encuentra ubicada  en el recinto Soloma, perteneciente al Cantón Echeandia, esta ventanilla se dedica a lobores Agrícolas de ciclo corto siembra de maíz, arroz, maracuyá esta actividad llevan mucho tiempo haciéndolo.

Angel Armando se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz y arroz, maracuyá. Compra sus productos en el Comercial Viscarra y vende los  productos en el Comercial Escudero.
